item.title: Covid: 'Rash' Christmas rules 'will cost many lives'
item.description: Officials from the four UK nations are to discuss the plans, as top medical journals call them a "blunder".

item.title: Coronavirus: Greenwich Council backs down on school closures
item.description: It comes as the government ordered the council to keep schools open until the end of term.

item.title: High death rate 'may be starting to fall'
item.description: Total deaths in the UK have been 20% above normal in recent weeks, but that figure has now dropped.

item.title: Covid: Twelve charts on how Covid changed our lives
item.description: From cancelled operations to benefit claim rises, how has the pandemic impacted peoples' lives?

item.title: 'Huge expansion' of secondary school Covid tests in January
item.description: Secondary-school pupils in England who have been in contact with a positive case will have daily tests.

item.title: Nigeria's Katsina school abduction: Boko Haram says it took the students
item.description: The Islamist militant group's leader Abubakar Shekau says it opposes Western education.

item.title: Hospitality worst-hit as unemployment rises again
item.description: UK loses 819,000 paid jobs since start of pandemic, with a third of the cuts in hospitality.

item.title: Blackpool baby death: Man charged with murdering daughter
item.description: Four-month-old Willow Lee was found seriously injured on 3 December and died three days later.

item.title: Jack Grealish: Aston Villa captain banned from driving
item.description: The England and Aston Villa player has also been hit with an £80,000 fine.

item.title: Scotland's drug death crisis in six charts
item.description: More than 1,200 people died of drug-related deaths in Scotland, the highest ever total.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell: Jeffrey Epstein associate seeks $28.5m bail deal
item.description: Ms Maxwell denies charges that she helped the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein groom young girls.

item.title: Universal credit: 'I felt guilty claiming benefits for the first time'
item.description: Women under the age of 30 have seen one of the sharpest increases in universal credit claims since March.

item.title: Cartoonist Charlie Mackesy: 'Don't give up, the storm ends'
item.description: Cartoonist Charlie Mackesy dedicated his drawings to the people on the front line tackling Covid-19.

item.title: Stargazers watch the total eclipse in Argentina's Neuquen province
item.description: Tourists and scientists gathered at an observation site in Argentina to witness the total eclipse.

item.title: Nottingham street dancer: ‘Why I dance in front of strangers’
item.description: Jamal Sterrett performs a style known as bruk up.

item.title: Experiencing a lockdown world through hang gliding
item.description: Hang glider Wolfgang Siess lost his job due to coronavirus, so he started filming his flights to try and attract more people to the sport.

item.title: Yemen: How Covid-19 spread in a war zone
item.description: Already facing a humanitarian crisis, Yemenis have been left in the dark over the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: How do we know new vaccines are safe?
item.description: The NHS is carrying out the biggest mass vaccination campaign in its history - what safety checks were made?

item.title: Australia storms: Dog rescued and beaches damaged as extreme weather hits coast
item.description: Hazel disappeared under a sea of foam at Byron Bay as wild weather battered the coast.

item.title: MasterChef final is dream come true for Nepal’s Santosh Shah
item.description: Getting to the MasterChef final is like a dream for Santosh Shah, who is from a tiny village in Nepal.

item.title: 'We'd just begun our careers - and then the pandemic hit'
item.description: The sudden lockdown in March turned the world of work upside down for millions, including the very newest, apprentices.

item.title: New Covid strain: How worried should we be?
item.description: Scientists will keep a close eye on this variant to see if it is a better spreader than others.

item.title: Hunger spikes, demand rises for US food banks
item.description: Amid the pandemic, one in eight Americans say their household has experienced a food shortage.

item.title: A palm oil alternative could help save rainforests
item.description: Plantations for palm oil are blamed for rainforest destruction, but an artificial palm oil is close.

item.title: Senegal's Dakar Fashion Week: The catwalk in a baobab forest
item.description: Held outside because of the pandemic, a fashion show in Senegal embraces the environmental message.

item.title: How fact met fiction in Le Carré's secret world
item.description: The novelist's career was shaped by his experience of espionage - and influenced the work of spies.

item.title: Brexit: 'It's utter confusion' over trade talks delay
item.description: Business across Britain tell BBC News of their frustration at post-Brexit trade talks being extended.

item.title: Bosman at 25: Who has been the best free transfer?
item.description: From Zlatan Ibrahimovic to Jay-Jay Okocha - who has been the best free transfer in the 25 years of the Bosman ruling?

item.title: Houllier was a special man, says his former captain Gerrard
item.description: Steven Gerrard says he is finding it "really hard to come to terms" with the death of "special man" Gerard Houllier, his former Liverpool manager.

item.title: Only egos will stop Fury v Joshua happening - promoter Warren
item.description: The only thing preventing an all-British heavyweight bout between Tyson Fury and Anthony Joshua are "egos", says promoter Frank Warren.

item.title: Any Pogba move to be in summer as January transfer 'difficult', says agent
item.description: Paul Pogba is likely to stay at Manchester United until next summer as it would be "difficult" to sort out a move in January, says his agent.

item.title: Sports Personality of the Year: Hollie Doyle on her record-breaking day at Windsor
item.description: Sports Personality of the Year contender Hollie Doyle reflects on a record-breaking day at Windsor where she rode five winners and reveals what motivated her to a win at Royal Ascot.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What Covid tier is your area in and what are the restrictions?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Christmas Covid rules: Who are you allowed to see?
item.description: Restrictions will be eased, but health experts have urged people to think carefully about mixing.

item.title: Covid: What are the new tiers and lockdown rules in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions for socialising, travel and hospitality vary around the UK.

item.title: Covid: What are the quarantine rules when arriving in the UK?
item.description: Travellers arriving from almost all other countries must self-isolate on entry to the UK.

item.title: Covid: Will schools close early for Christmas?
item.description: Schools are adopting measures to reduce the spread of coronavirus and keep pupils safe.

item.title: Covid: Can I go on furlough and how much will I be paid?
item.description: More people are now eligible for furlough, with the scheme extended until March 2021.

item.title: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Brexit: What you need to know about the UK leaving the EU
item.description: Time is running out for the UK and EU to strike a deal - what is happening now?

item.title: Brexit: What would no deal mean?
item.description: What will it mean if there is no deal between the UK and EU by the end of the year?

item.title: Brexit: What would no deal mean for Ireland’s economy?
item.description: The Irish government has been clear that it would face significant damage if there was no agreement.

item.title: Brexit trade deal: What do WTO rules or an Australia-style relationship mean?
item.description: If the UK leaves the EU without a trade deal it will have to trade on WTO terms.

item.title: Brexit: What are the UK and EU doing to prepare for no deal?
item.description: With no deal looking increasingly likely, how have both sides been getting ready?

item.title: Where do the UK's main political parties stand on Brexit now?
item.description: With pressure mounting on securing a trade deal for post-Brexit Britain, we look at MPs' positions.

item.title: Brexit: Will you still be able to take your pet to Europe? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about Brexit.

item.title: Pound falls on the prospect of a no-deal Brexit
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it is 'very, very likely' the UK will not secure terms with the EU.

item.title: Brexit: 12 key words you need to know
item.description: From free trade agreement to no deal, find out what the key terms mean.

item.title: Could Brexit make my food more expensive?
item.description: The UK is negotiating a new trade deal with the EU - how might the result affect food prices?

item.title: Travel after Brexit: How will it affect my holidays to the EU?
item.description: A simple guide to how leaving the EU will affect travel to Europe.

item.title: Brexit: What trade deals has the UK done so far?
item.description: Securing a UK-EU trade deal is a top priority in the weeks ahead.

item.title: Brexit trade deal: What are the sticking points?
item.description: The negotiating teams have been working "day and night" - what are the remaining issues still to be agreed?

item.title: Brexit: What will happen in Northern Ireland?
item.description: Why is Northern Ireland different, and how will things change after 1 January 2021?

item.title: Brexit: Seven things changing in January and others that remain unresolved
item.description: The UK's future relationship with the EU remains uncertain - but some things will be different in 2021.

item.title: Fishing: Why is fishing important in Brexit trade talks?
item.description: Fishing remains one of the biggest arguments in the UK's trade negotiations with the EU.

item.title: ‘I was in prison at 20 - and a music executive by 28’
item.description: As he faced jail, the life Niyah Smith had once dreamed of looked impossible. But then came a chance to turn his fortunes around.
